import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib as mlp




# Read in the Problem 1 Results
prob1 = pd.read_csv('./data/problem1_results.csv')
# print(prob1)
# taking the x and y values
x = prob1['Name']
y = prob1['max_departure_delay']

# normalizing to get color gradient
norm = plt.Normalize(y.min(), y.max())
colors = plt.cm.Reds(norm(y))

# plotting horizontal bars
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.barh(x, y, align='center', color=colors)
ax.set_xlabel('Maximum Departure Delay (mins)') # axis titles
ax.set_ylabel('Airline')
ax.set_title('Maximal Depature Delay by Airline')
plt.tight_layout() # layout so words are cut
# saving the plot
plt.savefig('./output/prob1_fig')

# displaying the plot
plt.show()

# https://matplotlib.org/stable/gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/barh.html#sphx-glr-gallery-lines-bars-and-markers-barh-py












# Read in the Problem 2 Results
prob2 = pd.read_csv('./data/problem2_results.csv')
# print(prob2)
# taking the x and y values
x = prob2['Name']
y = prob2['max_early_departure']

# normalizing to get color gradient
norm = plt.Normalize(abs(y).min(), abs(y).max())
colors = plt.cm.Greens(norm(abs(y)))

# plotting horizontal bars
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.barh(x, y, align='center', color=colors)
ax.set_xlabel('Maximum Early Departure (mins)')
ax.set_ylabel('Airline')
ax.set_title('Maximal Early Depature by Airline')
plt.tight_layout()
# saving the plot
plt.savefig('./output/prob2_fig')

# displaying the plot
plt.show()

# https://matplotlib.org/stable/gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/barh.html#sphx-glr-gallery-lines-bars-and-markers-barh-py












# Read in the Problem 3 Results
prob3 = pd.read_csv('./data/problem3_results.csv')

# Getting each of the data columns
days = ['Sun', 'Mon', 'Tues', 'Weds', 'Thurs', 'Fri', 'Sat']
flights = [74954, 97754, 91668, 93480, 78087, 78217, 65798]
ranks = [6, 1, 3, 2, 5, 4, 7]

# Creating the bar plots of the days and number of flights
fig, ax1 = plt.subplots()
# making specific colors for best and worst days
bar_colors = ['tab:grey', 'tab:red', 'tab:grey', 'tab:grey', 'tab:grey', 'tab:grey', 'tab:green']
ax1.bar(days, flights, color=bar_colors)
ax1.set_ylabel('Num of flights')
ax1.set_xlabel('Day')
ax1.set_title('Number of flights by all Airlines')

# Creating the second plot of rank
ax2 = ax1.twinx()
ax2.plot(days, ranks)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig('./output/prob3_fig.png')
plt.show()

# https://matplotlib.org/stable/gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/bar_colors.html#sphx-glr-gallery-lines-bars-and-markers-bar-colors-py
# https://matplotlib.org/stable/gallery/subplots_axes_and_figures/two_scales.html












# Read in the Problem 4 Results
prob4 = pd.read_csv('./data/problem4_results.csv')
print(prob4)

# getting the values
airport = prob4['Airport_Name']
airport_name = prob4['Airport_Name'].iloc[0]
delay = prob4['Avg_Delay']
code = prob4['Airport_Code']

# putting a line break in the airport title
airport_label = airport_name.replace("PA:", "PA:\n")

# plotting a lollipop plot
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(6,2))
ax.hlines(y=airport_label, xmin=0, xmax=delay, color='red')
ax.plot(delay, airport_label, 'o', color='red')
ax.set_xlabel("Average Departure Delay (mins)")
# getting rid of the axes
for spine in ['top', 'right', 'left']:
    ax.spines[spine].set_visible(False)

# saving and displaying
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig('./output/prob4_fig.png')
plt.show()

# Read in the Problem 5 Results
prob5 = pd.read_csv('./data/problem5_results.csv')

# See power BI for visual





# Read in the Problem 6 Results
prob6a = pd.read_csv('./data/problem6a_results.csv')
prob6b = pd.read_csv('./data/problem6b_results.csv')
print(prob6a)

# getting the variables
airports = prob6b['Name']
reasons = prob6b['Reason']
num_cancel = prob6b['num_cancellations']

# taking only the top 5
airports_top10 = airports[:5]
reasons_top10 = reasons[:5]
num_cancel_top10 = num_cancel[:5]

# taking only the bottom 5
airports_bot10 = airports[-5:]
reasons_bot10 = reasons[-5:]
num_cancel_bot10 = num_cancel[-5:]

# plotting a lollipop plot of top 5 and bottom 5
fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 1, figsize=(8,6))
axes[0].hlines(y=airports_top10, xmin=0, xmax=num_cancel_top10, color='red')
axes[0].plot(num_cancel_top10, airports_top10, 'o', color='red')
axes[0].set_xlabel("Average Departure Delay (mins)")
axes[0].set_title("Top and Bottom 5 Airports for Average Departure Delay")

axes[1].plot(num_cancel_bot10, airports_bot10, 'o', color='green')
axes[1].set_xlabel("Average Departure Delay (mins)")

# saving and displaying
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig('./output/prob6_fig.png')
plt.show()

# Read in the Problem 6 Results
prob6b = pd.read_csv('./data/problem6b_results.csv')

# getting the variables
airports = prob6b['Name']
reasons = prob6b['Reason']
num_cancel = prob6b['num_cancellations']

reasons = prob6b.groupby("Reason")["num_cancellations"].sum()
reason_labels = ['Carrier', 'National Air System', 'Security', 'Weather']
cancels = [449, 570, 55, 1231]
explode = (0, 0, 0, 0.1)
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.pie(cancels, explode=explode, labels=reason_labels, autopct='%1.1f%%', shadow=True)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig('./output/prob6_2_fig.png')
plt.show()

# https://matplotlib.org/stable/gallery/pie_and_polar_charts/pie_features.html#sphx-glr-gallery-pie-and-polar-charts-pie-features-py












# Read in the Problem 7 Results
prob7 = pd.read_csv('./data/problem7_results.csv')

# getting the variables
prob7["date_clean"] = prob7["FlightDate"].str.replace("2023-", "", regex=False) # removing the year
date = prob7['date_clean']
avg_flights = prob7['avg_num_flights']

# plotting the time series
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10,6))
ax.plot(date, avg_flights, color='blue')
plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha='right') # rotating the dates
plt.xlabel('Date (May 2023)')
plt.ylabel('Avg number of flights')
plt.title("Average Number of Flights over Preceding 3 Days")
plt.grid(True, alpha=0.3)

# adding red dot for worst day
dot_red = pd.to_datetime('05-26-2023')
dot_red_str = dot_red.strftime("%m-%d")
y_value = avg_flights[prob7["date_clean"] == dot_red_str].values[0]
plt.scatter(dot_red_str, y_value, color='red', zorder=5)

# adding green dot for best day
dot_green = pd.to_datetime('05-30-2023')
dot_green_str = dot_green.strftime("%m-%d")
y_value = avg_flights[prob7["date_clean"] == dot_green_str].values[0]
plt.scatter(dot_green_str, y_value, color='green', zorder=5)

# plotting and saving
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig('./output/prob7_fig.png')
plt.show()

title: April Showers Bring May Delays:  Optimizing Travel and Avoiding Delays for the Month of May
text:
Explanation of Project
The following sections outline recommendations for how and when to travel based on data collected for the month of May in 2023.
The data comes from the United States Department of Transportationâ€™s Bureau of Transportation Statistics1. It details Passenger Travel that is reported by the US air carriers. The data is meant to measure on-time performance of aircrafts and the distrribution of delays across airports and airlines. In addition, it includes information on the time period, the origin and destination airport, the airline, cancellations, flight summaries, and diversions. The data is reported on a monthly basis and each observations represents a single flight.
With this collected data, the following sections will investigate the major contributors to delays and which airports and airlines are to be avoided. It will also look at time trends in terms of the best days to travel. The data only encompasses previous trends in the month of May, thus, this project is best suited for a person looking to travel in May and hoping to avoid massive delays and travel issues.
So when and how should you travel? Scroll through to find out.

title: April Showers Bring May Delays:  Optimizing Travel and Avoiding Delays for the Month of May
text:
Travel Days
The first question to answer is what day of the week you should travel and, furthermore, what specific date should you travel?



Figure 1. Average Number of Flights over Preceding 3 Days2


In the above figure 1, we see that the minimum day for average number of flights is May 30th. What this indicates is that the 3 days preceding (ie. May 27th, 28th, and 29th) have the lowest average number of flights over the course of May. On the other side, we see that May 26th has the highest three days preceding average, thus May 23rd, 24th, and 25th are the busiest days in terms of number of flights. With these two pieces of information in mind, it seems late May after the 26th is the best time to travel. Around May 8th, May 16th, and May 23rd are also good days to partake in air travel. Finally, May 23-27 are the worst days to travel.


Figure 2. Number of flights by all Airlines3 4


Moving more in-depth to the specific days of the week, we see in Figure 2 that based on number of flights the busiest day of the week is Monday, followed closely by Wednesday. The best day is Saturday, with Sunday coming in at the second best day. The other days, Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday are somewhat neutral.

title: April Showers Bring May Delays:  Optimizing Travel and Avoiding Delays for the Month of May
text:
Airline
With timing in mind, you now have to buy a ticket and decide which airline to book with. The consideration is often based on availability and pricing, but it is also important to arrive on-time and avoid being stuck at the airport all day, so choosing a reliable airline matters.



Figure 3. Maximal Departure Delay by Airline5


Here, we see the airlines with the maximal departure delay, meaning the airline with the single longest delay for a flight takeoff. We see that American Airlines has the highest delay time, coming in at over 3000 minutes or about 50 hours. Allegiant Air and JetBlue Airways come in second and third with delay times around 1500 mins (~25 hours).



Figure 4. Maximal Early Departure by Airline6


On the other side of things, we see the airlines with the maximal early departure delay, meaning the airline with the single earliest takeoff for a flight. This airline is Frontier Airlines, which took off an hour early, followed by Alaska Airlines at about 55 minutes, followed by SkyWest Airlines at about 40 minutes early. Interestingly, we see that SkyWest has the most inconsistent departure times as they come in 4th for longest delay and 3rd for earliest delay.

title: April Showers Bring May Delays:  Optimizing Travel and Avoiding Delays for the Month of May
text:
Airport
Another important consideration is the specific airport to depart from. For most people this is a choice of the closest airport to their home, however, when you live in a large metropolitan area and have a choice of travelling a bit further to a different airport it may save you time in the long run. It is also important to consider the airport you may be passing through in you layover as delays are particularly difficult in this situation.



Figure 5. Airport with Highest Average Departure Delay7


Our first consideration is Figure 5, which shows the worst airport is terms of average depature delay. This airport is the Lehigh Valley International Airport in Pennsylvania, with average delays of over 2 hours. In the case of needing to fly in this area, it may be worth the hour trip to Philadelphia International Airport to avoid some delays.



Figure 6. Average Departure Delay by Airline and Airport8


Next, we see the average departure delay by the combination of an Airline and Airport. It seems that for Frontier Airlines, the worst airport is the Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Aiport. For Allegiant Airlines, the Lehigh Valley International Airport again shows major delays. The Lehigh Valley International Airport also appears with SkyWest and PSA Airlines. The Albuquerque International Airport appears for American Airlines, JetBlue, Spirit Airlines, Delta Air Lines, and United Air Lines. Overall, these three airports are a good idea to avoid, especially, if flying with one of the airline combinations listed.



Figure 7. Top and Bottom 5 Airports for Average Departure Delay9


Finally, we look at the overall 5 worst and best airports for departure delays. The worst overall airport is the Dallas/Fort Worth International Aiport, followed closely by Denver International and again we see the Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International showing major delays.
In terms of efficient airports, Greater Rochester International, James M Cox/Dayton International, Merie K Mudhole Smith, Joe Foss Field, and Rochester International are reliable airports for getting airplanes off the ground on time.

title: April Showers Bring May Delays:  Optimizing Travel and Avoiding Delays for the Month of May
text:
Other Considerations
Finally, we investigate cancellations of flights, which can be an even bigger headache than a departure delay. For this we attempt to discover the main reasons for cancellations across all airports and airlines.



Cancellation
Count




Not Canceled
576,679


Cancelled
3,310




Table 1. Number of Flights Cancelled.

We see that, thankfully, the majority of flights are able to take off (although many experience delays) and that only about 3,000 flights during the month of May were forced to be cancelled, which equates to only a 0.57% cancellation rate.


Figure 8. Percentage of Cancellations by Reasons10

Figure 8 shows that, unsurprisingly, the biggest contributor to cancellations is weather. This is likely due to the number of rain and thunderstorms we see in the height of spring in May. This is followed by National Air System delays, which means that Air Traffic Control is delaying the flight to cancellation because of air traffic volumne, runway issues, or other safety hazards. In third is Carrier delays, which means the Airline itself cancelled the flight for a variety of issues including mechanical issues, short staffing, or fueling issues. Finally, issues of security account for only 2.4% of cancelled flights.

title: April Showers Bring May Delays:  Optimizing Travel and Avoiding Delays for the Month of May
text:
Final Recommendation
Ultimately, the choice to travel will depend on the availability of flights, specific geographic location, and holidays and events that dictate travel. In addition, we can never fully predict weather and other extenuating circumstances that will cause delays, cancellations, and other travel day headaches.
However, there is no harm in making an informed decision based on historic data about flight patterns and departure delay trends. Thus, for a person looking to travel in the month of May, I offer these basic recommendations to hopefully make travel slightly more efficient:

Travel on Saturday or Sunday.
Avoid May 23-27 if possible.
Stay away from American Airlines, Allegiant Air, and JetBlue if possible.
Never use the Lehigh Valley International Airport (travel to PHL), Hartsfeld-Jackson Atlanta International, or Albuqerque International.
Use Rochester International (MN), Joe Foss Field (SD), Merle K Mudhole Smith (AK), James M Cox/Dayton International (OH), or Greater Rochester International (NY) if in these areas.
Stay ahead of the forecast and try to avoid big storms.
Arrive enough in advance in case delays do occur.

Other than that, stay prepared for delays and cancellations as the data shows that overall, air travel is an unreliable and seldom on-time type of travel.
